bibl.title: Letter from Wenceslao Pareja to Wickliffe Rose, May 29, 1921

div1.p: Pareja, in this letter translated from Spanish to English, writes to Rose regarding his appointment as Director of Health. He details efforts taken to eliminate yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Wenceslao Pareja to Wickliffe Rose, May 29, 1921
div1.opener:
c o p y
DMH
6-21, 1921
Translated from the Spanish
REPUBLIC OF ECUADOR
HEAD OF DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH
Guayaquil, May 29, 1921
Dr Wickliffe Rose
General Director of the International Health Board
New York
Dear Doctor:
div1.p:
It is with the greatest pleasure that I reply to your
kind letter of the 2nd instant, and thank you for your congratulations
on my appointment as Director of Health.

The Minister was so good as to communicate to me the
remarks as to the appearance and spread of yellow fever in the North of
Peru, of which we have taken due note. Further, Dr Henry Carter had an
interview with me, at the time of his visit to this port, during which he
gave me detailed information on the situation in Peru with regard to
yellow fever. As a consequence of this conversation and of the subsequent
data which we have received, I found it necessary to extend the quarantine
measures to all the ports adjacent to the infected zone, in view of the
facility and frequency of communication between the said ports.

Upon Dr Hanson's request, I sent you some species of fish
(millions, huaijas and chalacos) which have given good results in this city.
In this, as in all other matters within my power, we shall try to co-operate
in the task of eradicating yellow fever.

For our part, in Guayaquil strict vigilance is continually
maintained over the water receptacles, with the same organization that has
been functioning for the last two years. I can assure you that the Govern-
2.
ment and the inhabitants of this city are so thoroughly convinced of
the importance of this work that will not be altered for any reason,
and in the remote eventuality of any person suffering with yellow fever
entering the country, this disease could not spread, since the number of
Stegomyias is so reduced that we may consider it as the irreducible and
harmless index. At present many foreigners and persons coming from the
interior are visiting the city, without any case, even a suspicious one,
having occurred. At the time of writing a fleet of North American
submarines is also visiting our port; the crews came ashore at once, and
are wandering around through the city happily. Guayaquil is as free of
yellow fever as Havana and Panama. This is due undoubtedly to the
beneficent action of the Board over which you preside, and in view of that
fact I shall take special care to communicate to you the sightest incident
bearing on this matter.

I am very happy to learn of the triumph obtained by the
Board in Mexico and in Central America, and I wish to congratulate you on
it with all the more pleasure since our good and generous friends, Dr Connor,
General Lyster, Dr Bailey and so many others that the good judgment of the
Board knows how to choose, are connected with this work.
I repeat that as for Guayaquil there is nothing to be feared.
With assurances of my deep respect, I remain,
div1.closer:
(signed) W. Pareja Dr W Pareja
Director of Health
Guayaquil, Ecuador
